 The problem being that there are no fast answers to either the war in Iraq or the war in Afghanistan. 
 
 The Iraqi government is going to have one short chance to keep the peace when we leave, and if they don't step up to the plate ready to hit one out of the park, Iraq will be embroiled in a massive civil war within a few months of our departure. 
 
 Afghanistan seems to be even more of a problem. The US recognized government is simply a puppet regime with little power. Afghanistan is ruled by tribal leaders who look to clerics for their direction. These tribal leaders garner almost blind support by the local publics, either by fear and intimidation or the use of religious rhetoric. The US had had to learn a new way to fight war. We went into Iraq and Afghanistan with a WWII mentality that we would be greeted as liberators. We quickly found that the people welcome you with smiles on their faces and bombs in their pockets. We are slowly adjusting to a new type of warfare, but if we are not ready to hit hard with massive force, we are going to lose in Afghanistan.
